newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil wins court boost in CVRD sale battle.
newsitem.headline: Brazil wins court boost in CVRD sale battle.

text.p: The Brazilian government won a crucial boost on Monday in its battle to privatise mining giant Companhia Vale do Rio Doce (CVRD) when a high court threw out a series of legal challenges.
Officials said two or three injunctions remained blocking Latin America's largest state sell-off to date from taking place but government lawyers would rush to contest them on Tuesday.
"Tomorrow perhaps we will have good news," said Jose Pio Borges, privatisation director of the National Development Bank, which runs Brazil's privatisation programme.
The sale of 45 percent of CVRD's voting stock was due to have begun on April 29 but has been delayed repeatedly by court action.

The government appealed to the Superior Court of Justice in Brasilia, the country's highest court for non-constitutional matters, arguing that all lawsuits should be considered by a single tribunal because of a "conflict of interpretation".

An official at the court said Justice Democrito Reinaldo agreed with the government's view, quashing all the injunctions included in the government's petition and naming a federal court in Rio de Janeiro as the tribunal responsible for all new cases.
Borges, however, said two or three injunctions remained.

"Tomorrow we will examine how best to overturn these injunctions," Borges told reporters, adding the government could either appeal to a federal court in Rio de Janeiro or ask the Superior Court of Justice to extend its ruling to the new cases.
Brazil hopes to raise at least $5 billion from the sale of the world's largest iron ore exporter, making it the biggest Latin American privatisation to date.
But the sell-off of the jewel in the Brazilian public sector's crown has been controversial.
Demonstrators clashed with police in downtown Rio last week and a chorus of criticism has risen from past presidents, Catholic bishops and the judiciary.
Monday's O Globo newspaper said the delay was beginning to irritate the leader of one of the two consortia bidding.

"It's a very unpleasant situation," Globo quoted Antonio Ermirio de Moraes, chief executive of Brazil's largest private conglomerate Votorantim, as saying. Votorantim heads the Valecom consortium together with South Africa's Anglo American Corp.
Moraes said Brazil was putting on a "Third World show" and complained that the delay was costing his partners money.
According to Globo, the government also was losing out, having had to spend $280,000 on the documents for its high court case alone.
